awd_titl_txt: Polarization-Resolved Single-Photon Measurements of Nonlinear Thomson Scattering
awd_abstract_narration:
Advances in laser technology have made it possible to create exceptionally bright light inside a tiny region where a laser beam is focused.  This project will develop a new way to study the optical fields near such a laser focus.  The electric and magnetic fields in such extreme light can rip electrons away from any substance and then accelerate the electrons at more than sextillion (thousand billion billion) g's, where one g is the acceleration due to gravity on Earth.  The freed electrons are then propelled to very near the speed of light, so Einstein's equations of relativity are required to describe their motion.  Electrons under these extreme conditions scatter wavelength-shifted light out of the laser focus (called nonlinear Thomson scattering), and this can reveal the dynamics of the electron motion and thus the structure of the laser fields.   This research team has developed techniques to distinguish the scattered photons from the quintillion background photons that comprise the laser pulse that drives the electrons.  With this project, the team will use the scattered light as a probe to map the strength and polarization of the optical fields in and around the focus.  Such a laser focus is challenging to characterize in any other way, since the focus is often as small as an individual pixel on a camera.  Furthermore, at full power any camera placed in the focus would be destroyed.  Analysis of the electric and magnetic fields inside a very intense but tiny laser focus will be helpful for understanding interactions between laser light and atoms, molecules, and solids that are studied with the world's most powerful lasers.  This project will also provide an opportunity for students to be trained on optics and photonics technologies and contribute to progress in fundamental science.

The ability to measure individual photons scattered from only a few electrons in a laser focus enables observation of fundamental relativistic phenomena at very low densities (essentially a vacuum).  This will allow this team to avoid the confounding influence of plasma dynamics that occur for higher densities.  They will study the polarization of nonlinear Thomson scattering in the spatial distribution of the scattered fundamental, second, and third harmonic light.  The polarization contains an added dimension of information, which has not previously been investigated or measured.  The rich structure in polarization-resolved scattering plots promises new insights into electron dynamics. This team's simulations of relativistic electron trajectories within a tight laser focus show that electron trajectories are sensitive to the details of the field vectors of the laser. The use of a deformable mirror will allow them to create ideal and exotic focal shapes to test the sensitivity of nonlinear Thomson scattering to the details of the vector field distributions in the focus.

por.por_cntn:
We measured nonlinear Thomson scattering from free electrons in an intense laser focus. We observed fundamental, second-harmonic, and third-harmonic light emitted in directions perpendicular to the laser propagation.  We resolved the emitted light into polarization components, which has not been previously investigated. At laser intensities above 10^18 W/cm^2, free electrons move at near the speed of light and strongly interact with both the electric magnetic fields of the laser.  This causes the electrons to execute figure-8 like motion.  We demonstrated that the individual dimensions of the electron figure-8 motion give rise to distinct polarization components of the scattered light.  This represents the first unambiguous experimental proof of electron figure-8 motion at relativistic intensities, something that was first predicted nearly a century ago.  Numerical simulations show that one polarization component of the scattered light arises solely from the up-and-down motion of the figure-8, while the other polarization component arises solely from the side-to-side motion of the figure-8.

We used single-photon counting to record the scattered light from repeated laser pulses.  This permitted relatively low electron density in the focus, avoiding potentially confounding influences of plasma dynamics.  High-intensity lasers and photon counting are traditionally thought of as opposite experimental regimes, even incompatible.  Our experiments are unique in that they successfully merge high-power laser physics with the research field of quantum optics. While electrons are stimulated by a laser pulse with 10^18 photons, we detect signals comprised of individual scattered photons. 

We demonstrated that polarization-resolved scattered radiation reveals details of the vector electric and magnetic field vectors in the intense laser focus. For example, the scattered signal is sensitive to both the focal spot size and the pulse duration, as electrons can be pushed out of the focus by the strong field gradients before the laser pulse finishes.  This limits the amount of time electrons can scatter photons.  This may prove to be a useful diagnostic of focused high-power laser pulses, which are notoriously challenging to characterize.
